diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum, fifth disease)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Streptococcal Pharyngitis
diagnoses.details: A bacterial infection that can make your throat feel sore and scratchy. Streptococcus pyogenes bacteria causes this condition.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.details: Often called mono or the kissing disease, this infection is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and can lead to fever, sore throat, swollen lymph glands, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.details: A disease that can occur as a result of a group A Streptococcus (group A strep) infection. The signs and symptoms include a sore throat, fever, headaches, swollen lymph nodes, and a characteristic rash.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.details: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's more common in children. The symptoms include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, irritation and redness of the eyes, swollen lymph nodes, and redness of the mouth, lips, and throat.

diagnoses.name: Acute HIV Infection
diagnoses.details: The initial stage of HIV, presenting symptoms similar to flu, including fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Gonococcal Pharyngitis
diagnoses.details: A sexually transmitted infection of the throat caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Symptoms can include sore throat and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Herpangina
diagnoses.details: An illness caused by a virus, characterized by small blister-like bumps or ulcers on the roof of the mouth and in the back of the throat.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus Infection
diagnoses.details: A virus causing a range of illnesses, throat redness, swelling, and fever. It can lead to conditions like conjunctivitis, bladder infection, and pneumonia among others.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, including painful mouth and genital sores, acne-like skin lesions, and swollen joints.

diagnoses.name: Diphtheria
diagnoses.details: A serious bacterial infection usually affecting the mucous membranes of your throat and nose. Symptoms include sore throat, swollen glands, and weakness.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. The excess iron is stored in various organs, particularly the liver. Symptoms can include joint pain, abdominal pain, fatigue, and weakness. Hyperferritinemia is a key marker, although hypoferritinemia is unlikely unless there is concurrent iron loss.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. The primary symptoms are dry eyes and dry mouth, but it can also cause fatigue and joint pain. Sjögren's syndrome could be associated with bronchitis due to the dryness of the mucous membranes and irritated eyes as a primary symptom.

diagnoses.name: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing. It is typically caused by long-term exposure to irritating gases or particulate matter, often from cigarette smoke. Patients with COPD may have elevated ferritin levels due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Iron overload
diagnoses.description: Occurs when there is too much iron in the body. This condition can be caused by frequent blood transfusions, hemochromatosis, or consuming high levels of dietary iron. Symptoms include liver disease, heart problems, and diabetes. Both hypoferritinemia and hyperferritinemia can be present depending on the stage and specific condition causing the overload.

diagnoses.name: Anemia of chronic disease
diagnoses.description: A type of anemia that occurs in chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, chronic kidney disease, and other chronic conditions. The disease interferes with the body's ability to use stored iron for making red blood cells, leading to hypoferritinemia. However, ferritin levels may be misleadingly normal or high as it is an acute-phase reactant.

diagnoses.name: Acute bronchitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the bronchial tubes, the airways that carry air to your lungs. It causes a cough that often brings up mucus, as well as wheezing, fever, and chest tightening. It can be caused by viral infections, bacterial infections, or exposure to pollutants. The condition itself doesn’t usually affect ferritin levels but could be a secondary symptom to a systemic condition affecting iron metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Allergic conjunctivitis
diagnoses.description: An eye inflammation caused by allergic reactions to substances like pollen or mold spores. Symptoms include red, watery, itchy eyes, and may also involve a stuffy nose and sneezing. While not directly related to bronchitis or ferritin levels, it can co-occur with systemic allergic reactions that could impact overall health.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Asthma can lead to or coexist with chronic bronchitis. There’s no direct link to ferritin levels, but inflammation associated with asthma could theoretically affect them.

diagnoses.name: Still's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare form of arthritis characterized by high fevers, rash, and joint pain. It can also cause inflammation of internal organs such as the heart and lungs. Hyperferritinemia is a common finding due to systemic inflammation, and eye symptoms could also be present.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and the brain. Patients may experience a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, joint pain, rash, and lung problems. SLE can lead to both hyper and hypoferritinemia depending on the phase of the disease and organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. Dysautonomias and attention deficits can be associated symptoms due to neurological involvement.

diagnoses.name: Eustachian Tube Dysfunction
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects the tube connecting the middle ear to the nasopharynx, causing difficulty in balancing ear pressure and fluid. This can lead to otitis media and can be associated with otitis externa indirectly through related infections.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction that causes sneezing, congestion, and sinus pressure. It can lead to complications such as otitis media and otitis externa due to inflammation and infection. Dry eyes and attention deficit can be associated symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the nerves that control involuntary bodily functions are damaged. It's part of the dysautonomias category, might cause dry eyes due to reduced tear production, and can be indirectly related to ear infections.

diagnoses.name: ADHD (Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development. It doesn't directly cause the ear conditions but can coexist with dysautonomias and sensory sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the sinuses that lasts more than three months. It can cause or exacerbate otitis media and otitis externa. Dry eyes and dysautonomias may also be present due to associated inflammation and nervous system impact.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus affects the immune system and can lead to Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. This condition can predispose individuals to various infections, including otitis media and otitis externa. Dry eyes and dysautonomias can occur due to the overall impact on the body.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs. Host Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when donor bone marrow or stem cells attack the recipient. It can cause dry eyes and various autoimmune responses that may indirectly link to ear infections and dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, which is transmitted by ticks. It can affect many parts of the body, including the nervous system, potentially leading to dysautonomias, and indirectly involve the ears through cranial nerve impact.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, brain, blood cells, and ears. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including dry eyes, ear infections, and dysautonomias.

diagnoses.explanation: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth. It can also lead to fatigue and anxiety due to its chronic nature and the body's reaction to autoimmune stress.
A disorder affecting the large intestine, causing symptoms like diarrhea, cramping, and abdominal pain. Anxiety and stress can worsen or trigger the symptoms of IBS.
Conditions such as hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism can lead to dry eyes, anxiety, and changes in bowel habits. Thyroid hormones can affect various body systems, leading to a wide range of symptoms.
A condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It can also include symptoms of anxiety and physical sensitivities.

A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. It can include symptoms of sleep abnormalities, pain, and sensitivities.
While primarily a mental health disorder, depression can manifest in physical symptoms such as gastrointestinal upsets (like diarrhea), appetite changes, and somatic complaints.
Anxiety can contribute to gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea, as well as exacerbate conditions such as dry eyes through physiological stress responses.
An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Symptoms include diarrhea, bloating, and anemia, which can indirectly lead to anxiety through chronic illness.

A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs, causing dry eyes, fatigue, joint pain, and potentially leading to miscarriage in severe cases.
Though not a diagnosis per se, the hormonal and physical changes during pregnancy can exacerbate conditions like IBS or anxiety, and unfortunately lead to complications such as miscarriage.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) associated with other underlying conditions
Human Papillomavirus Infection (HPV) - Considering warts and possibly leukoplakia
Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID) - Related to decreased immunoglobulins
Oral Leukoplakia - Specifically for the leukoplakia
Chronic Fatigue Syndrome - Considering non-restorative sleep and potential immune dysfunction
Secondary Immunodeficiency - Potential cause of decreased immunoglobulins
Oral Squamous Papilloma - Considering warts and leukoplakia
Autoimmune Disorders - Some may cause decreased immunoglobulins and other symptoms
Chronic idiopathic urticaria (for easy bleeding due to skin fragility)
Esophageal varices (in the context of severe GERD and portal hypertension)
Rheumatoid arthritis (systemic effects can include hypothyroidism and easy bleeding)
Sjögren's syndrome (can cause hypothyroidism and gastrointestinal issues)
Chronic liver disease (can lead to hypothyroidism, easy bleeding, and other symptoms)
Thrombocytopenic purpura (for easy bleeding, other symptoms would be secondary)
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) / Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, leading to cardiovascular issues such as aneurysms, skeletal abnormalities, and sometimes eye problems.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks its own tissues and organs, potentially leading to lymphadenitis among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect the connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues, potentially causing aneurysms and dysautonomia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. It features granulomas, small clumps of immune cells in the body.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can affect arteries, veins, and capillaries. It may cause chest pain and is potentially linked to aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Familial Mediterranean Fever
diagnoses.description: An inherited inflammatory disorder that causes recurrent fevers and painful inflammation of your abdomen, lungs, and joints.

diagnoses.name: Loeys-Dietz Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by the enlargement of the aorta, the large blood vessel that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body, and aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Disorders
diagnoses.description: Include a variety of diseases such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), which may lead to symptoms like constipation.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to numerous symptoms including chest pain and issues affecting various organs.

diagnoses: Urinary tract infection (in the context of incontinence)

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These foreign substances are called allergens. They can include certain foods, pollen, or pet dander. Symptoms include rhinorrhea, angioedema, and sometimes pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction. It can occur within seconds or minutes of exposure to something you're allergic to, such as peanuts or bee stings. Symptoms can include angioedema, pruritis, vomiting, and in some cases, incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Renal Failure
diagnoses.description: A gradual loss of kidney function. Over time, the kidneys can't filter blood as well as they should. This can lead to incontinence due to the body's inability to control urine output, and in some cases, patients may experience vomiting and pruritis due to accumulated toxins.

diagnoses.name: Food poisoning
diagnoses.description: An illness caused by eating contaminated food. Infectious organisms — including bacteria, viruses and parasites — or their toxins are the most common causes of food poisoning. Symptoms can include vomiting and sometimes incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the liver. Causes can include viral infections, alcohol abuse, and certain drugs. Symptoms can vary and may include vomiting and pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder that affects the large intestine. Symptoms can include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and in some cases, incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammation of the skin resulting from direct contact with an irritant or allergen. This condition may cause pruritis and in severe reactions, can lead to symptoms like rhinorrhea or angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction
diagnoses.description: Adverse effects that occur with the administration of drugs. Symptoms can vary depending on the drug and the individual but can include vomiting, pruritis, angioedema, and in rare cases, incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear. In some cases, severe anxiety can lead to physical symptoms including incontinence, vomiting, and in association with panic attacks, even pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever. Incontinence can occur as a severe symptom, especially in viral gastroenteritis.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including severe headaches, nausea, light, and sound sensitivity. Scintillating scotoma is a common visual aura.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by muscle tightness in the head, neck, or scalp. It is often associated with stress, anxiety, or muscular tension.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by recurrent, severe headaches on one side of the head, often around the eye. Cluster headaches are known for their pattern of occurring in clusters over weeks or months.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. It can cause numbness and weakness and is a warning sign for potential future strokes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause numbness, weakness, and in some cases, visual disturbances like scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the surrounding membrane (the subarachnoid space), potentially causing headache, numbness, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, and stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause headaches, weakness, numbness, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is cut off, causing tissue damage. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, and numbness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: Anxiety can sometimes manifest physical symptoms including headache, muscle weakness, and numbness, alongside psychological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause symptoms such as vomiting, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A severe headache often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light, sometimes preceded by sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection, presenting symptoms like vomiting, weakness, and possible neurological deficits like aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding within the brain tissue itself, a life-threatening type of stroke, causing sudden symptoms including vomiting, weakness, and possibly aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain often caused by an infection, leading to symptoms including fever, seizures, vomiting, weakness, and problems with speech or hearing.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, possibly causing weakness and difficulty in speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain owing to an infection, presenting symptoms like headache, vomiting, aphasia, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it presents with stroke-like symptoms such as weakness and speech difficulties but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Specific types of seizures may lead to symptoms like aphasia and weakness post-seizure.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech (aphasia), and headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to the brain. It can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, such as aphasia and weakness, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves neurological disturbances, such as scintillating visual phenomena, aphasia, and sensory changes like numbness or tingling. Headaches may accompany the aura or follow it.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. Symptoms can include numbness, weakness, difficulty with coordination and balance, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor involves the growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Depending on the tumor's location, it can cause headaches, weakness, numbness, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Certain types of seizures may cause aphasia and scintillation prior to onset.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain caused by a viral infection or other factors. It can lead to headaches, fever, confusion, weakness, and sensory problems like numbness or tingling.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck, along with potential confusion, numbness, and weakness depending on the severity and spread of the infection.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Lupus is a systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, headache, numbness, and weakness, depending on which body systems are affected.

diagnoses: Psychotic disorder due to another medical condition
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, HTLV-1, Hepatitis C)
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Epstein-Barr virus)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia combined with Thrombocytopenia)
